title: 105_s1512
content: The "Cargo Theft Deterrence Act of 1997" may be cited as the Act. It pertains to interstate or foreign shipments by carriers. The "Cargo Theft Deterrence Act of 1997" amends Section 659 of title 18, United States Code by removing the term "with intent to convert to his own use" and making various additions and changes to paragraphs related to theft penalties. The Act pertains to interstate or foreign shipments by carriers. The "Cargo Theft Deterrence Act of 1997" amends Section 659 of title 18, United States Code by allowing the court to reduce penalties for defendants who provide information leading to the arrest and conviction of stolen goods dealers. Goods and chattel are considered to be moving as an interstate or foreign shipment from the point of origin to the final destination. The "Cargo Theft Deterrence Act of 1997" amends Section 659 of title 18, United States Code by adding an affirmative defense for defendants who bought, received, or possessed goods with the intent to report to law enforcement. The Act also mandates a sentencing enhancement of at least 2 levels for offenses under this section. The "Cargo Theft Deterrence Act of 1997" amends Section 659 of title 18, United States Code by adding an affirmative defense for defendants who bought, received, or possessed goods with the intent to report to law enforcement. The Attorney General must submit an annual report to Congress evaluating law enforcement activities related to the investigation and prosecution of offenses under this section. The "Cargo Theft Deterrence Act of 1997" establishes an Advisory Committee on Cargo Theft. The "Cargo Theft Deterrence Act of 1997" establishes the Advisory Committee on Cargo Theft, composed of 6 members appointed by the President, including representatives from the Department of Justice, Department of Transportation, Department of the Treasury, and experts in cargo security from the private sector. The Advisory Committee on Cargo Theft, established by the "Cargo Theft Deterrence Act of 1997," consists of 6 members appointed by the President, including representatives from various government departments and private sector cargo security experts. Appointments must be made within 30 days of the Act's enactment, with members serving for the life of the Committee. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Committee must hold its first meeting within 15 days of all initial members being appointed and meet at least quarterly at the Chairperson's call. A majority of members constitutes a quorum. The Committee shall conduct a study on establishing a national computer database for information on violations of section 659 of title 18, United States Code, and an office within the Federal Government to enhance cargo security coordination. The President selects the Chairperson, and a majority of members form a quorum for hearings. The Committee will increase coordination between the Federal Government and the private sector for cargo security. A report will be submitted to the President and Congress within a year of the Act's enactment. The Committee has the power to hold hearings, gather information from federal agencies, and take necessary actions to fulfill its objectives. The Committee has the authority to request information from federal departments and agencies, use postal services, and accept gifts. Non-federal members will be compensated for their service. The Committee members are entitled to daily pay equivalent to level IV of the Executive Schedule under title 5, US Code, while federal members serve without additional compensation. Travel expenses, including per diem, are allowed at authorized rates. The Chairperson of the Committee has the authority to appoint an executive director and additional staff without following civil service laws. The compensation for these personnel can be determined by the Chairperson without adhering to specific provisions of title 5, US Code. The Chairperson of the Committee can appoint an executive director and staff without following civil service laws. The pay for these personnel should not exceed the rate for level V of the Executive Schedule. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Committee without reimbursement, maintaining their civil service status. The Chairperson can also procure temporary services at specified rates. The Committee's pay rates for individuals should not exceed level V of the Executive Schedule. The Committee will terminate 90 days after submitting the report. Appropriations are authorized for the Committee's purposes without fiscal year limitation.
